metadata.case_name: Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal

facts.text: Appellant company carries on business of manufacturing and selling sugar at factory in Sehore, Madhya Pradesh.

During year ending September 30, 1950, purchased 7,72,217 maunds sugarcane from local cultivators at 14 centers 8-22 miles from factory at Rs. 1-4-6 per maund fixed by Bhopal State; average transport cost Rs. 0-4-9 per maund.

Grew own sugarcane 6,78,490 maunds; claimed market value Rs. 1-13-0 per maund including Rs. 0-4-9 transport, total Rs. 12,29,763; deducted agricultural expenses Rs. 9,77,772 (harvesting, loading etc.), claimed balance Rs. 2,51,991 as agricultural income for assessment year 1951-52.
ITO accepted expenses Rs. 9,77,772 but computed market value at Rs. 1-6-0 per maund, total Rs. 9,33,000, resulting in loss Rs. 44,772; no deduction of agricultural income.
Appeal to AAC Jubbalpore: determined market value Rs. 1-7-9 per maund, total Rs. 10,07,132, agricultural income Rs. 29,360 allowed as deduction.

Appeal to Tribunal Bombay: claimed Rs. 1-13-0; Tribunal held market under r.23 is factory, not centers; direct ITO to ascertain average transport from centers to factory, add to Rs. 1-4-6 per maund; if exceeds Rs. 1-7-9, give further relief.
CIT applied for reference u/s 66(1) Income-tax Act on ground Tribunal not justified adding transport to Rs. 1-4-6; withdrawn August 4, 1954; Tribunal order final and binding.

Appellant requested ITO to implement Tribunal directions; after correspondence, ITO on March 24, 1955 refused relief: misinterpreted as transport from farms (debited Rs. 59,116), computed total Rs. 9,28,431 < Rs. 10,07,132, no relief.
Appellant filed petition u/Art. 226 before Judicial Commissioner Bhopal for mandamus to compel ITO.
JC found ITO acted arbitrarily, violated Tribunal directions illegally; but examined Tribunal order, held wrong on r.23, no manifest injustice, dismissed petition on February 14, 1956.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate u/Art. 133.

legal_issues.text: Whether Judicial Commissioner rightly dismissed petition u/Art. 226 for writ of mandamus to compel ITO to carry out Tribunal directions.

petitioner_arguments.text: ITO failed to carry out Tribunal directions by misreading 'centers' as 'farms' and using actual debited transport instead of average from centers to factory.

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal order directed transport from farms; used actual expenses Rs. 59,116 debited; market value does not exceed AAC rate.
Tribunal order unintelligible; did best to understand.

court_reasoning.text: ITO misread Tribunal direction (centers to factory, not farms); refused to carry out superior tribunal order, acting illegally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subordinate tribunal must carry out directions of superior tribunal; refusal is denial of justice, chaos in administration.

court_reasoning.text: JC erred in examining correctness of final Tribunal order; not sitting in appeal; even if wrong, cannot disregard.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal order final after reference withdrawn; basic principle of hierarchy of courts.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal order clear: add average transport from centers to Rs. 1-4-6.

holdings.text: Subordinate tribunal must obey directions of superior appellate tribunal; refusal destructive of justice administration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; petition for mandamus

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Market value of sugarcane for agricultural income

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; JC order set aside; writ of mandamus issued directing ITO to carry out Tribunal directions by ascertaining average transport charges from centers to factory and adding to Rs. 1-4-6 per maund for market value.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus to ITO to implement Tribunal order

key_quotes.text: If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal in the exercise of its appellate powers, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle upholding hierarchy of tribunals

key_quotes.text: We find no difficulty in understanding the order of the Tribunal it directed the respondent to ascertain the average transport charges per maund from the centers to the factory and add to it the rate of Rs. 1-4-6 per maund of sugar-cane.
key_quotes.speaker: court
